title: Paul Gascoigne fights back tears recalling sexual assault allegation
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Paul Gascoigne fought back tears while discussing the sexual assault case which ended last week, admitting he could have taken the ‘easy’ way to cope by turning to alcohol again.

The former England midfielder was found not guilty of sexual assault during a four-day trial last week, after being accused of ‘forcefully’ kissing a woman on a train in August 2018.

While speaking about his ordeal on Good Morning Britain, Paul became overwhelmed with emotion as he explained how he remained ‘strong’ with the help of sponsors.

Paul, who has been sober for six months, told Kate Garraway and Ben Shepherd that he wanted to sit console a woman who had been called ‘fat and ugly’ by another passenger on the train.

‘I thought I’d give her a bit of confidence and never thought anything of it,’ Paul told the presenters.

‘I admit that [I kissed her], I said that straight away.

‘She’s not fat and ugly. I didn’t feel her in a sexual way, I didn’t look at it that way. I sat with my lawyers who said what could happen.’

Paul has opened up about his ‘difficult’ year (Picture: ITV)

When asked whether he was scared after being arrested, Paul revealed: ‘Not at first, I think I was more scared when I sat with my lawyers.

‘Obviously I did get worried and could have taken the easy way with alcohol but I stayed strong through it.’

The 52-year-old recalled how he found comfort throughout the ordeal in the support of the public.

He added: ‘I spent the whole year telling people I didn’t do anything wrong. Every time I felt like drinking I just rang my sponsors.’

Paul was cleared last week at Teesside Crown Court but wasn’t in a celebratory mood.

‘I didn’t feel I had anything to celebrate, it’s been a tough year. I’d say the rest of my life depended on this,’ he explained.

Paul was cleared last week (Picture: Reuters)

‘I’m so thankful to the judge and the jury who saw common sense in all of this.’

Despite the seriousness of the allegations, Paul says he would still act the same way as he simply wanted to make the woman feel better about herself after the nasty comments regarding her appearance.

‘No, I don’t think I’ll ever change. I am who I am. I just don’t think it was right for her to be called what she was called, fat and ugly,’ Paul admitted.

‘I’ve always been a nice, caring guy.’

However, he did state: ‘Obviously I’m more cautious, there are people out there trying to stab you in the back.’

Paul is now focusing on getting his life back on track and is working on a movie about his life.

Good Morning Britain airs weekdays at 6am on ITV.
